meanings.definition: to continue to do or work on something:

meanings.definition: to produce something quickly and easily:

meanings.definition: to murder someone:
examples: He hired a hitman to knock off a business rival.

meanings.definition: to have sex with someone
to reduce the price or value of something by a particular amount:
examples: The manager knocked off ten bucks because the dress had a few buttons missing.

meanings.definition: to stop working or doing something:
examples: The carpenter knocked off early to take his kid to baseball practice.

meanings.definition: to remove by pushing, hitting, or other forceful action:
examples: A low branch knocked her off her horse.
One of the side mirrors on the truck got knocked off.

meanings.definition: to stop working, usually at the end of the day:
examples: I usually try to knock off early on a Friday.
We didn't knock off work until 7:30.

meanings.definition: to produce a cheap copy of someone else's product, usually illegally:
examples: Small companies may see their inventions knocked off before they can make any money from them.

meanings.definition: to take a particular amount away from a price, value, etc.:
examples: Living next door to an empty home can also knock 10% off the value of your own property, say experts.
Customers can knock hundreds of dollars off their energy bills by following three simple steps.
The supermarket joined the fuel price war yesterday by knocking 5 cents a liter off its petrol and diesel prices.

meanings.definition: said in order to avoid bad luck, either when you mention good luck that you have had in the past or when you mention hopes you have for the future:
examples: The deal will be agreed on Wednesday, knock on wood.

meanings.definition: I hope my good luck will continue:
examples: I never have trouble with my car, knock on wood.

knock-out-of-the-park.name: knock sb/sth out of the park

meanings.definition: to do something much better than someone else, or to be much better than someone or something else:
examples: Hotel Ferrero knocks everyone out of the park with their breakfast.
The BBC is hitting them all out of the park at the moment, in children's drama at least.

meanings.definition: to do something extremely well:
examples: I feel like I can write anything for this actor, and she'll knock it out of the park.
If I don't hit this out of the park, I'm finished.

meanings.definition: to say no to someone who has offered you something or asked you to do something:
examples: He asked her out but she knocked him back.
The singer was repeatedly knocked back by record companies who said he was too old.

meanings.definition: to cost someone a large amount of money:
examples: I bet that computer knocked you back several hundred.

meanings.definition: to quickly drink something, especially a lot of alcohol:
examples: She was knocking back the champagne at Maria's party.
He raised the glass to his lips, then knocked it back in a single gulp.

meanings.definition: to say no to someone's offer, idea, etc.:
examples: It was too good an offer to knock back.
His plan was knocked back by the council.

meanings.definition: to have a bad effect on someone or something, especially by stopping them from achieving something:
examples: Disappointing results from the company knocked its shares back to just 51p.
She missed out on the promotion, but refused to be knocked back.

meanings.definition: to refuse to accept or agree to something:
examples: The proposed merger of the two companies was knocked back by competition authorities in Australia.
Ofgem's role is to approve that pricing regime, and it has twice knocked back what the company is proposing.

meanings.definition: to hit someone with a vehicle and injure or kill them:
examples: She was knocked down by a bus.

meanings.definition: to cause someone or something to fall to the ground by hitting him, her, or it
to reduce a price, or to persuade someone to reduce the price of something they are selling:
examples: She wanted $200 but I knocked her down to $175.

meanings.definition: to destroy a building or part of a building:
examples: There are plans to knock the library down and replace it with a hotel complex.

meanings.definition: to show that what someone has said is not true :
examples: She easily knocked down every argument he put up.

meanings.definition: (of a price) extremely cheap:
examples: They're selling jeans for ridiculous knock-down prices.

meanings.definition: to hit someone or something forcefully so that it falls down, or falls to a lower place:
examples: Try not to knock the fence down when you back out of the driveway.

meanings.definition: to destroy and remove a building, wall, or other structure:
examples: The city is going to knock the old train station down and build a new library.

meanings.definition: To knock down a system, practice, rule, etc. means to get rid of it:
examples: He wants to use the WTO to knock down trade barriers.

meanings.definition: to reduce the price, amount, or value of something:
examples: He wanted $300 for the ring, but we got him to knock it down to $250.
The SEC knocked down their $1.5 billion penalty to $500,000.

meanings.definition: to persuade someone to reduce the price of something they are selling:
examples: She wants $120 for the bike, but I'll try and knock her down to $90.

meanings.definition: to reduce the price of something you are selling, or persuade someone to reduce the price of something they are selling:
examples: They managed to knock the price down from €290,000 to €220,000 .

meanings.definition: extremely cheap or much lower than the usual amount:
examples: a knock-down deal/price/rate
They are offering a full broadband internet service for a knock-down £17.99 a month.

meanings.definition: very serious and damaging:
examples: The company has had a knock-down blow.

meanings.definition: used to describe furniture that is sold in pieces that must be joined together:
examples: a knockdown bookcase/desk/table

meanings.definition: to shock or upset someone very much, or to make someone very ill:
examples: The news of his death knocked me for six.
The experience had knocked him for six.
I had a bad case of flu that knocked me for six.
Being betrayed by someone you trust can really knock you for six.
When I heard the news yesterday I was knocked for six, devastated.

meanings.definition: to show people that someone is not as perfect as they seem to be:
examples: This recent scandal has really knocked the president off his pedestal.

meanings.definition: to hit someone so that they become unconscious:
examples: His opponent knocked him out with one punch.

meanings.definition: If a drug or alcohol knocks you out, it makes you go to sleep:
examples: The sleeping tablets knocked him out for 18 hours.

meanings.definition: to defeat a person or a team in a competition so that they can no longer take part in it:
examples: The champion was unexpectedly knocked out of the tournament in the first round.
England were knocked out after losing the final game of the round.

meanings.definition: to cause enjoyment or admiration in someone:
examples: We were all really knocked out by the film.

meanings.definition: to make yourself unconscious, usually by hitting your head:
examples: She hit her head on the ceiling and knocked herself out.

meanings.definition: to make yourself ill with tiredness:
examples: If you carry on working like this, you'll knock yourself out.

meanings.definition: to produce something quickly without spending time thinking about the details:
examples: I've knocked out a first draft of the report that we can amend at a later date.

meanings.definition: If something such as a piece of equipment is knocked out by something else, it stops working or is damaged or destroyed:
examples: The surge in the power supply knocked out all the computers.
Enemy aircraft have knocked out 25 tanks.

meanings.definition: to hit someone so that the person becomes unconscious, or to cause someone to go to sleep:
examples: His fall from the ladder knocked him out.
Those sleeping pills knocked me out.

meanings.definition: If something such as a system or piece of equipment is knocked out by something else, it stops operating:
examples: The lightning knocked out our electricity.

meanings.definition: to remove something, esp. by hitting it with force:
examples: Sean fell off his bike and knocked two teeth out.

meanings.definition: A person or team that is knocked out of a competition is defeated and no longer can take part:
examples: A loss in today’s game will knock our team out of the playoffs.

meanings.definition: to produce something quickly without spending time thinking about the details:
examples: Modern computer games take a long time to develop; you can no longer knock one out in three months.

meanings.definition: to stop a machine, system, etc. from working:
examples: Powerful storms knocked out electricity to more than a million customers in the area in July.

meanings.definition: to hit someone with a vehicle and injure or kill them:
examples: She got knocked over by a taxi as she ran for the bus.

meanings.definition: to hit something, especially forcefully, and make it fall :
examples: Who knocked over that mug of coffee?
The wind knocked my garden furniture over.

meanings.definition: to steal something
to hit something or someone so that the person falls down:
examples: Who knocked over the chair?
Cyclists in the race have to worry about fans knocking them over.

meanings.definition: to shock or upset someone very much, or to make someone very ill:
examples: That flu really knocked me sideways.
Losing the case knocked her sideways and she lost a lot of weight.
The allegations have knocked him sideways and he denies them all.
He was knocked sideways by the sudden death of a friend.
Their complacency is knocked sideways when they receive a threatening message.

meanings.definition: If you say that you will knock someone's block off, you are threatening to hit them very hard, especially on the head:
examples: I'll knock his block off if he tries anything with me!

knock-into-a-cocked-hat.name: knock something into a cocked hat

meanings.definition: to be much better than something else:
examples: a show that knocks all the others into a cocked hat

meanings.definition: to prevent something from happening, or to finally finish something:
examples: It's nearly done - another couple of hours should knock it on the head.

meanings.definition: If a quality is knocked out of someone, they lose that quality because the situation they are in does not allow it to exist:
examples: Any creativity I had was soon knocked out of me at school.

meanings.definition: to make something quickly and without much care:
examples: I could knock together a quick lunch if you like.

meanings.definition: to be much better than something or someone else:
examples: It knocks spots off that restaurant in Cotswold Street.

meanings.definition: to make the value of something go down by a particular amount:
examples: A warning of significant losses knocked 10p from the group's shares.

knock-the-bottom-out-of.name: knock the bottom out of something

meanings.definition: to damage something severely, especially by destroying its support:
examples: The rise in mortgage rates really knocked the bottom out of the housing market.

meanings.definition: If you knock one room into another room, or knock through a room, you remove the wall between one room and the next so that they form one room:
examples: We're planning to knock the kitchen into the dining room to make one large eating space.
Food was served through a hatch knocked through the kitchen wall.
The previous owners had knocked the living room into the dining room to make a large open-concept gathering space.
You could turn this into a full-sized bedroom if you just knock into the walk-in closet.
You could knock through the hallway to make the living room wider.

meanings.definition: Players knock up before beginning a game of tennis or similar sport by hitting the ball to each other:
examples: The players have a couple of minutes to knock up before the match starts.

meanings.definition: to wake someone up by knocking on the door of their house or bedroom:
examples: I'm sorry to have to knock you up in the middle of the night.

meanings.definition: to make a woman pregnant:
examples: You don't want to get knocked up by some guy you hardly know.

meanings.definition: a short time before the start of a game of tennis or a similar sport when players practise by hitting the ball to each other:
examples: Let's have a quick knock-up before the game.

meanings.definition: a way of describing the sound made when you hit a door. It is sometimes used as the first line of a joke.
a knock-down-drag-out fight or argument is very serious and continues for a long time:
examples: Look, I don't want to get into a knock-down-drag-out fight with you over this, so let's forget it.

meanings.definition: (of an argument or physical fight) lasting a long time and energetically fought:
examples: We had knock-down drag-out fights, but when I really needed him on the big issues, he was helpful.

meanings.definition: an agreement between insurance companies in which each pays the claims of its own clients following an accident, whether or not their client is to blame
If someone is knock-kneed, their knees bend towards each other.
a person who knocks on someone's door for an invented reason and then enters their house in order to steal things:
examples: Three knock-knock burglars have been caught on tape.

meanings.definition: an occasion when a person knocks on someone's door for an invented reason and then enters their house in order to steal things:
examples: Knock-knock burglaries are on the rise.
The men are suspected of working as a knock-knock burglary crew.

meanings.definition: When an event or situation has a knock-on effect, it causes other events or situations, but not directly:
examples: If one or two trains run late, it has a knock-on effect on the entire rail service.

meanings.definition: to take action to get something or someone into the good condition that you would like:
examples: to knock the economy into shape
A better teacher would have licked him into shape.

knock-take-the-stuffing-out-of.name: knock/take the stuffing out of someone/something

meanings.definition: to make someone or something become very weak:
examples: Her illness has really knocked the stuffing out of her.

meanings.definition: If something that happens knocks you for a loop, it upsets or confuses you because you do not expect it:
examples: He knocked me for a loop when he said he was quitting his job.

meanings.definition: (especially of a theatre performance) causing laughter by very silly behaviour
an occasion when someone refuses to go out with, accept, employ, etc. another person:
examples: If a man approaches a woman and gets a clear knockback, that should be the end of it.
Every knock-back seems to deflate her.

meanings.definition: (of the price of something) reduced by a lot:
examples: They quickly realised why the property was available at a knockdown price.
The game is now selling for a knockdown £6 in B&M stores.

meanings.definition: cheap, or reduced in price by a lot:
examples: They are selling the knockdown fuel for just over 50p a litre.
Hundreds of bargain hunters descended on the market, drawn by the promise of knockdown art.

examples: She knocked on the window to attract his attention.

meanings.definition: to criticize, especially unfairly:

These all sound like knock-offs of Abba songs to me.

meanings.definition: A knockoff product, etc. is a cheaply made or less good copy of a popular or high-quality one:
examples: His jeans were held up with a knockoff designer belt.
Beware of knock-off Olympic memorabilia.

meanings.definition: a cheaper copy of an expensive and popular product:
examples: She bought a knockoff of a designer suit.

meanings.definition: a cheap and sometimes illegal copy of a popular, more expensive product:
examples: Would you buy a knockoff of an expensive dress?

meanings.definition: in boxing, the act of hitting the other fighter so that they fall to the ground and are unable to get up again within ten seconds:
examples: a knockout punch/blow

meanings.definition: a competition in which only the winners of each stage play in the next stage, until one competitor or team is the final winner:
examples: The tournament is a straight knockout.
a knockout competition/championship

meanings.definition: a person or thing that looks, sounds, etc. extremely attractive:
examples: Your sister's a real knockout!

meanings.definition: extremely attractive:
examples: She looked knockout in that dress.

meanings.definition: (in boxing) a situation in which a fighter falls after being hit and cannot get up in ten seconds:
examples: He won by a knockout in the tenth round.

meanings.definition: a very attractive person or thing:
examples: She was a real knockout in her new dress.

meanings.definition: an offer to buy something that is higher than competitors' offers:
examples: His bid was seen as a knock-out and shares of competing companies fell.
a knockout bid/offer/price

meanings.definition: a drug, usually put secretly into your drink, that makes you sleep
a type of thick smoked sausage originally from Germany:
examples: The tavern serves a German sausage sampler featuring knockwursts, bratwursts, and beef frankfurters, and a variety of mustards.
We got some knackwurst to cook on the grill .

meanings.definition: a small low hill with a rounded top:
examples: a grassy knoll

meanings.definition: a small hill with a rounded top
a join made by tying together the ends of a piece or pieces of string, rope, cloth, etc.:
examples: Tie a knot in the rope to hold it in place.

meanings.definition: a tight mass, for example of hair or string:

meanings.definition: a small group of people standing close together:

meanings.definition: a small hard area on a tree or piece of wood where a branch was joined to the tree

meanings.definition: to form a tight, hard, rounded mass:
examples: His muscles knotted (= swelled) with the strain.

meanings.definition: a fastening made by tying together a piece or pieces of string, rope, cloth, etc.:
examples: Wrap this string around the package and then tie a knot.
fig. She’s so nervous, her stomach is in knots (= feels tight and uncomfortable).

meanings.definition: a group of people or things:
examples: After the game, disappointed knots of people drifted away.

meanings.definition: a hard, dark area on a tree or piece of wood where a branch was joined to the tree
a measure of speed for ships, aircraft, or movements of water and air equal to approximately 6076 feet (1.85 kilometers) an hour
a measure of the speed of ships, aircraft, or movements of water and air. One knot is approximately 1.85 kilometres per hour:

meanings.definition: joined by having been tied together in a knot, or containing a knot or knots:
examples: a knotted rope
a knotted handkerchief

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         knot

examples: It was a very knotty problem.

meanings.definition: with a lot of knots:

meanings.definition: (of a tree or piece of wood) covered with hard, dark areas where branches were joined to the tree:
examples: knotty pine

meanings.definition: any of several wild plants with heart-shaped leaves, small flowers and divided stems:
examples: We do have native knotweeds in this country.
Cover the roots of knotweed with black plastic.

meanings.definition: art that consists of knots or that looks like knots, or the activity of creating art like this:
examples: Norse knotwork often has animal motifs such as dragons.
A lot of Celtic jewellery is decorated with knotwork patterns.
Classes range from knitting to decorative knot work.

meanings.definition: to have information in your mind:
examples: "Where did he go?" "I don't know."
"What does it cost?" "Ask Kate. She'll know."
She knows the name of every kid in the school.
I don't know anything about this.
We don't know when he's arriving.
I don't know (= understand) what all the fuss is about.
I just knew (that) it was going to be a disaster.
She knew (= was aware) (that) something was wrong.
Even small amounts of these substances are known to cause skin problems.
The authorities know him to be (= know that he is) a cocaine dealer.

meanings.definition: used to ask someone to tell you a piece of information:
examples: Do you know the time?
Do you know where the Post Office is?

meanings.definition: to be certain:
examples: I know (that) she'll be really pleased to hear the news.
I don't know whether I should tell her or not.
The party is at Sarah's house as/so far as I know (= I think but I am not certain).

meanings.definition: to be familiar with or have experience and understanding of:
examples: I've known Daniel since we were at school together.
She grew up in Paris so she knows it well.
I've seen the film "Casablanca" so many times that I know a lot of it by heart (= I know it in my memory).
Knowing Karen (= from my experience of her in the past), she'll have done a good job.
I have known (= experienced) great happiness in my life.

meanings.definition: If you know a subject, you are familiar with it and understand it:
examples: Do you know about computers?
She knows her subject inside out (= very well).

meanings.definition: If you know a language, you can speak and understand it:
examples: Do you know any French?

meanings.definition: to recognize someone or something:
examples: That's Peter alright - I'd know him anywhere!
I know a bargain when I see one.

meanings.definition: to have information in your mind; to be aware of something:
examples: “Where did he go?” “I don’t know.”
Do you know the answer?
She knows the name of every kid in school.
Do you know how to tap dance?
We don’t know when he’s arriving.
I knew (that) something was wrong from the start.
I want to know how much this will cost.

meanings.definition: to agree with or understand the reasons for an action or opinion:
examples: I don’t know what all the fuss is about.
“What a stupid movie!” “I know what you mean.”

meanings.definition: to be familiar with a person or place:
examples: I’ve known Vince since we were in elementary school.
She grew up in Hawaii so she knows it well.
Knowing Debbie (= from my experience of her in the past), she’ll do a good job.

meanings.definition: to feel certain about something:
examples: I know I’d enjoy myself if I went.
I know (that) I took those library books back.
I don’t know whether or not I should go to college.

meanings.definition: to feel certain about something:
examples: I know I’d enjoy myself if I went.
I know (that) I took those library books back.
I don’t know whether or not I should go to college.

meanings.definition: to recognize someone or something, or to recognize the difference between two people or things:
examples: That’s Pete – I’d know him anywhere.
I know a bargain when I see one!

know-a-hawk-from-a-handsaw.name: know a hawk from a handsaw

meanings.definition: to understand important differences or facts relating to a subject:
examples: The referee clearly doesn't know a hawk from a handsaw.
Until ministers learn to tell a hawk from a handsaw their drugs policy is bound to fail.

meanings.definition: If someone knows all the answers, they think they know much more than other people.

know-all-there-is-to-know-about.name: know all there is to know about something

meanings.definition: to know a lot about a subject or activity, or be very good at it
to be the most suitable person to have responsibility and make important decisions:
examples: When it comes to dealing with my own son, I think I know best.

meanings.definition: to have opinions that should be accepted and respected by other people:
examples: Mom knows best when it comes to investing money.

meanings.definition: to know more than someone else because you have more experience and more skill:
examples: They thought the painting was a fake, but Shackleton knew better.

meanings.definition: to be wise or moral enough not to do something:
examples: Sure, she's only six, but she's old enough to know better than to run off without us.
I'm surprised at you behaving so badly - you ought to/should know better.

meanings.definition: to be wise enough to behave in a more responsible or acceptable way:
examples: You know better than to interrupt when someone else is talking.

meanings.definition: to understand a situation completely:
examples: You know full well that you're not supposed to go there without asking me!
He knew full well what was happening but he couldn't be bothered to do anything about it.
She knew full well that it was risky.
They knew full well that what they were doing was illegal.
They know full well that this policy will have disastrous consequences for poor people but they don't care.

meanings.definition: to be able to do something because you have the necessary knowledge:
examples: Do you know how to print on this computer?
Read this book if you want to know how to succeed in business.
Baking is something she knows how to do very well.
Does anyone know how to disable the reboot feature?
We have a chainsaw, but I don't know how to use it.

meanings.definition: to have heard of someone or something and be able to give a small amount of information about him, her, or it:
examples: Do you know of a good doctor?

meanings.definition: to have heard the name of a person but not seen or talked to them:
examples: I know him by name, but I don't think I've ever met him.
His election campaign has only just got up and running, so most voters don't know him by name yet.
She didn't recognize me because she only knew me by name.
A lot of people in the crowd knew him by name and called out to him.
She was known only by name to most of the people invited.

meanings.definition: to know a person whom you do not see or talk with very often well enough that you know their name:
examples: She stayed at the hotel so often that she knew all the staff by name.
He's a huge movie star, but he took the time to get to know all the crew and knew them by name.
Their staff have worked intimately with them for years, and they still don't know them by name?
I visited the local pub so often while I was in town that the bartender knew me by name.
He's the sort of teacher who knows all his students by name after the first day of classes.

meanings.definition: If you know someone by sight, that person looks familiar to you, but is not a friend of yours:
examples: Mike spends a lot of time in this area, so you'd probably know him by sight.
I knew Jo's husband by sight, but I'd never really met him.
He walked up to Rose, whom he knew by sight.
The guards wouldn't let him enter because they didn't know him by sight.
I'll introduce myself to you father - I'm sure I'll know him by sight.

meanings.definition: to have very good and detailed knowledge of something:
examples: She knows her part in the play back to front.

meanings.definition: to know the difference between two things and therefore be able to recognize either, used especially to mean that you have a good knowledge and understanding of a particular subject:
examples: Computer expert? He doesn't know a mouse from a modem! (= He knows nothing about computers.)

meanings.definition: to know everything about a subject:
examples: He knows the system inside out.

know-like-the-back-of-hand.name: know something like the back of your hand

meanings.definition: to have very good and detailed knowledge of something:
examples: I know this area like the back of my hand.

know-like-the-back-of-your-hand.name: know something like the back of your hand

meanings.definition: to know a place very well:
examples: She’ll give you the name of a place to stay – she knows the area like the back of her hand.

meanings.definition: to know all the important facts in a situation, especially the unpleasant ones:
examples: You know the score - no payment till after the article is published.

meanings.definition: to be familiar with how it feels to be or do something:
examples: She knows what it's like to go bankrupt - it happened to her 20 years ago.

meanings.definition: to have the skills and knowledge to do something effectively:
examples: You don't need to tell me - I know what I'm doing!

meanings.definition: to have the knowledge or experience that is necessary to do something:
examples: Don’t worry about me – I know what I’m doing!

know-what-are-talking-about.name: know what you are talking about

meanings.definition: to understand a subject because of your experience:
examples: He doesn't know what he's talking about - he's never even been to Africa.

meanings.definition: to be able to speak in an informed way because of your experience or education:
examples: He doesn’t know what he’s talking about – he’s never even been to Alaska.

meanings.definition: If you know what's what, you have a lot of experience and can judge people and situations well:
examples: Linda's been in the business for 30 years - she knows what's what.

know-when-are-well-off.name: know when you are well off

meanings.definition: If you do not know when you are well off, you do not understand that your present situation is good compared with other people's or with what it might be like:
examples: She's always complaining about her car - she doesn't know when she's well off (= she's lucky to have a car even if it's bad)!

meanings.definition: to know what your opinion or situation is:
examples: I know where I stand on this issue - I'm against the war.
When we've paid all our debts we'll know where we stand.

meanings.definition: to be certain about what someone thinks or feels about you: to be certain about what your position and responsibilities are in a situation:
examples: He didn't even send me a birthday card, so I guess I know where I stand.
In the old days, the editor was completely in control, and we all knew where we stood.

know-which-side-bread-is-buttered-on.name: know which side your bread is buttered (on)

meanings.definition: to know who to be nice to and what to do in order to get an advantage for yourself
to be certain about what you believe or want
to accept your position within society, an organization, your family, etc. and to not want to improve it:

meanings.definition: to have good practical skills and knowledge in a particular activity or subject
to be familiar with a place or organization and able to act effectively within it

know-see-where-is-coming-from.name: know/see where someone is coming from

meanings.definition: If you say to someone you know or see where they are coming from, you mean you understand why that person has a particular opinion, often although you do not have that opinion:
examples: I would've taken the dog to the vet, but I could see where they were coming from.

meanings.definition: able to be known
showing that you know about something, even when it has not been talked about:
examples: a knowing look/glance/smile

meanings.definition: having or showing knowledge of private or secret information:
examples: My mother gave me a knowing smile.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows you know about something:
examples: She smiled knowingly at him.

meanings.definition: If you do something knowingly, you do it knowing what will be its likely effect:
examples: I've never knowingly offended him.

meanings.definition: while understanding the meaning of what you are doing:
examples: Many of them knowingly broke the law.

meanings.definition: understanding of or information about a subject that you get by experience or study, either known by one person or by people generally:
examples: Her knowledge of English grammar is very extensive.
He has a limited knowledge of French.
The details of the scandal are now common knowledge (= familiar to most people).
She started to photograph the documents, safe in the knowledge that (= knowing that) she wouldn't be disturbed for at least an hour.

meanings.definition: the state of knowing about or being familiar with something:
examples: They both deny all knowledge of the affair.
It has come/been brought to our knowledge (= we have discovered) that several computers have gone missing.

meanings.definition: awareness, understanding, or information that has been obtained by experience or study, and that is either in a person’s mind or possessed by people generally:

possess/lack knowledge

business/scientific/technical knowledge

meanings.definition: information or skills within a business that make it more valuable or competitive:
examples: Investors increasingly recognize the growing importance of knowledge assets in the way they value firms.
The knowledge capital of any organization is based on the knowledge and competencies held by its members.

meanings.definition: a collection of information about a particular subject:
